item.title: Indian Companies, Consumers Snub Pakistan and Its Allies
item.description: A growing number of Indian merchants, companies, and consumers are cutting business ties with Pakistan and some of its allies after a heightened conflict between the South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: Activists protest against Turkey in New Delhi on May 16.

item.title: US Loses Last Top Credit Rating With Downgrade From Moody’s
item.description: The US was stripped of its last top credit rating by Moody’s Ratings, reflecting deepening concern that ballooning debt and deficits will damage America’s standing as the preeminent destination for global capital and increase the government’s borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Grim Outlooks Take Centerstage as Tariffs Loom: Earnings Watch
item.description: One thing is clear as the first-quarter earnings season draws to a close: The uncertain outlook for the global economy is superseding better-than-feared results even as stocks rally on signs of easing trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey, Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Chicago Taps EY to Close $1 Billion Gap as Trump Threatens Funds
item.description: Chicago is hiring Ernst & Young LLP to help the city slash costs and close budget gaps that are forecast to top $1 billion in each of the next two years.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh

media:content.media:description: The skyline of Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024. Chicago is delaying its $643 million bond sale that was expected to price last week amid volatility in the $4 trillion market for state and local bonds.

item.title: Fed to Shrink Staff By About 10% Over Next Several Years
item.description: The Federal Reserve plans to shrink its system-wide workforce by about 10% over the next couple of years, mainly through attrition.
item.dc:creator: Annmarie Hordern, Saleha Mohsin, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Friday, Oct. 8, 2021. The Senate approved legislation Thursday that pulls the nation from the brink of a payment default with a short-term debt-ceiling increase, breaking a weeks-long standoff that rattled financial markets. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Russian Inflation Steadies as Key Rate Cut Expectations Build
item.description: Price growth in Russia halted its acceleration in April for the first time in six months, bolstering the case for kicking off long-awaited monetary easing amid signs of a sharp economic slowdown.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: A supermarket in Moscow. Source: Andrey Rudakov

item.title: US Consumer Sentiment Nears Record Low on Inflation Concerns
item.description: US consumer sentiment unexpectedly fell to the second-lowest level on record and inflation expectations climbed to multi-decade highs amid growing concerns about tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a sneaker store in New York.

item.title: ECB Will Include Trade Scenarios in June Projections, Lane Says
item.description: The European Central Bank will publish additional scenarios for the euro-zone economy alongside next month’s quarterly outlook in an attempt to capture the possible effects of the current trade turmoil, according to Chief Economist Philip Lane.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Philip Lane, chief economist of the European Central Bank (ECB), at the Institute of International Finance (IIF) during the annual meetings of the IMF and World Bank in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024. The International Monetary Fund lowered its global growth forecast for next year and warned of accelerating risks from wars to trade protectionism, even as it credited central banks for taming inflation without sending nations into recession.

item.title: Bernanke Urges Fed to Adopt ‘Alternative’ Forecast Scenarios
item.description: Former Federal Reserve Chair Ben S. Bernanke urged the US central bank to provide the public a fuller explanation of its interest-rate decisions and a much richer examination of potential forecast scenarios.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Ben S. Bernanke, former chairman of the US Federal Reserve.

item.title: Price Hikes Are Beginning to Threaten the American Consumer
item.description: For all the worry about tariffs causing pain for American consumers, shoppers have so far been mostly shielded from — or shrugged off — higher prices at the checkout aisle.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Jaewon Kang, Mark Niquette

item.title: What a Weaker US Dollar Means for the Economy
item.description: American exporters would benefit from the currency’s drop, but consumers could feel a pinch.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin

item.title: US Housing Starts Increase on Pickup in Multifamily Construction
item.description: US housing starts increased in April as a pickup in multifamily home construction more than offset a decline in single-family dwellings caused by elevated inventory.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: A contractor carries plywood on the roof of a house under construction in Folsom, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Romania Holds Interest Rates Before Tight Presidential Vote
item.description: Romania’s central bank kept borrowing costs unchanged just days before a presidential runoff that may determine prospects for tackling a budget crisis after months of political turmoil and a market selloff.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Portraits of historical rulers of Romania in Bucharest.

item.title: Trump Says US to Set Tariff Rates for Other Nations in Weeks
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would set tariff rates for US trading partners “over the next two to three weeks,” saying his administration lacks the capacity to negotiate deals with all of its trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, alongside Scott Bessent, left, and Howard Lutnick at the White House in February.

item.title: Swiss Had Good Exchange With US on Currency, SNB Chief Says
item.description: Switzerland has had productive talks with the US on the central bank’s currency interventions, Swiss National Bank President Martin Schlegel said, rejecting the suggestion that the country manipulates the franc’s exchange rate.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, president of the Swiss National Bank (SNB), displays a coin during the Swiss National Bank (SNB) annual general meeting in Bern, Switzerland, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The Swiss National Bank's gold holdings allowed the central bank to report a first-quarter profit, a respite before a recent surge in the franc hits its earnings.

item.title: Bessent Sees New Financial Forces Strengthening Economy, Dollar
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the US Treasury secretary’s endorsements of private credit and stablecoins. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: EU Economy Chief Urges China Self-Restraint on Diverting Goods
item.description: The European Union’s economy chief urged China to avoid flooding the European market with its goods as it seeks to avoid US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, trade commissioner for the European Union (EU), during a news conference following the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) meeting at the European Council headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. A top European Union policymaker said the region should take advantage of investor doubts in the dollar and US Treasuries.

item.title: APEC Trade Ministers Agree Statement Without Mentioning Tariffs
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies including the US and China agreed to focus on reforming global trade rules, after reaching an unexpected agreement by ignoring one of their biggest points of difference: tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Taicang Port Area International Container Terminal in Suzhou, China.

item.title: Treasuries, US-Made Japanese Cars Seen as Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Irish Exports to US Quadrupled in March on Tariff Threat
item.description: The value of exports from Ireland to the US quadrupled in March from a year earlier, on medical and pharmaceutical goods, the statistics office said.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Sample bottles at the production lab in the Eli Lilly & Co. manufacturing plant in Kinsale, Ireland.

item.title: Singapore Firms Up Exports During Pause in Trump’s Steep Tariffs
item.description: Companies in Singapore are expediting exports to take advantage of a 90-day pause in hefty tariffs proposed by the Trump administration, a top official in the city-state said.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: The Brani Terminal beyond the Keppel Harbour in Singapore, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. Singapore’s port, already one of the busiest in the world, is facing a sustained period of congestion as vessel diversions to avoid the Red Sea push more container ships to the Asian maritime hub.

item.title: EU Exports to US Surged Ahead of Trump’s Tariff Announcement
item.description: The European Union’s exports to the US rocketed in the month before President Donald Trump unveiled his so-called “Liberation Day” trade war with the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: Atlanta Fed’s Raphael Bostic on Monetary Policy During Extreme Uncertainty
item.description: How to keep the Fed's goals in balance with so much in flux.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Raphael Bostic, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market.

item.title: Odd Lots: Bostic on Fed Policy in Uncertain Times (Podcast)
item.description: This is obviously an extraordinarily difficult time to make economic forecasts. Nobody really knows how tariffs will effect the US economy. And beyond that, nobody knows what the ultimate state of tariffs will be, or if they’ll ever settle into a predictable rate. So how do you conduct monetary policy in this environment? item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Says He Sees One Rate Cut This Year, No Recession
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he expects the US economy to slow this year but not fall into recession, and reiterated that he sees one interest-rate cut in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Raphael Bostic, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, gestures as he speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023. Bostic said policymakers have time to watch how the economy is evolving and be patient when it comes to interest-rate moves.

item.title: What’s the De Minimis Tariff Loophole That Trump Closed?
item.description: A Latin term that used to be little-known outside the world of customs brokers has become the stuff of headlines this year. That’s thanks to a decision by US President Donald Trump to close a tariff loophole for “de minimis” merchandise from mainland China and Hong Kong from May 2.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Samson Ellis

media:content.media:description: Packages at a neighborhood sorting center in Beijing, China.

item.title: Czech Rate Setters Backed ‘Moderately Restrictive’ Stance in May
item.description: Czech central bankers agreed monetary policy needed to remain “moderately restrictive” to address persistent domestic price pressures and uncertain global economic outlook, minutes from the May 7 meeting showed.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

media:content.media:description: The city skyline seen from the roof of the Czech central bank headquarters in Prague, Czechia, on Tuesday, June 18, 2024. When Michl became governor the country was in the throes of its worst cost of living crisis in three decades and he pledged to bring inflation under control within two years, becoming one of the first central bankers in Europe to deliver on the goal.

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Doesn’t Reckon the World Is in a Currency War
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau dismissed a suggestion that a conflict in foreign-exchange policies is currently taking place.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Now ‘Relatively Close’ to Terminal Rate, Kazaks Tells CNBC
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Martins Kazaks said cuts in euro-zone borrowing costs are nearing their end-point if the base case for inflation returning to 2% this year materializes.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks, governor of the Latvian central bank, at the Financing a Better Future conference in Riga, Latvia, on Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2024. The economic revival in the euro area is likely to gain momentum, though dangers remain, according to European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg
